standard_metadata.standard_description: Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-digit numbers, using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

question.content: **Use partial products to multiply $73\times 42$.**  || -:|-: | :- |$73$ | |$\underline{{}\times 42}$ | Step 1| | $2 \times {}$  Step 2|$140$ | $2 \times 7$ tens Step 3|$120$ | $40 \times 3$ ones Step 4|$\underline{{}+2{,}800}$ | $40 \times 7$ tens Step 5| |

hints.content: Let's break up the top factor by place value.  Then we can multiply each part by $40$ and by $2$ to get parts of the product.  Finally, let's add up all of partial products to get the total product.
$\begin{align} 7\blueE{3}&\\ \underline{{} \times 4\maroonE{2}}&\\ \goldE{6}&\quad \maroonE{2} \times \blueE{3\text{ ones}} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} \blueE{7}3&\\ \underline{{} \times 4\maroonE{2}}&\\ 6&\quad {2} \times {3\text{ ones}}\\ \goldE{140}&\quad \maroonE{2} \times \blueE{7\text{ tens}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 7\blueE{3}&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{4}2}&\\ 6&\quad {2} \times {3\text{ ones}}\\ {140}&\quad {2} \times{7\text{ tens}}\\ \goldE{120}&\quad \maroonE{40} \times \blueE{3\text{ ones}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} \blueE{7}3&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{4}2}&\\ 6&\quad {2} \times {3\text{ ones}}\\ {140}&\quad {2} \times{7\text{ tens}}\\ {120}&\quad {40} \times {3\text{ ones}} \\ \underline{{}+\goldE{2{,}800}}&\quad \maroonE{40} \times \blueE{7\text{ tens}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 73&\\ \underline{{} \times 42}&\\ \purpleD{6}&\quad {2} \times {3\text{ ones}}\\ \purpleD{140}&\quad {2} \times{7\text{ tens}}\\ \purpleD{120}&\quad {40} \times {3\text{ ones}} \\ \underline{{}+\purpleD{2{,}800}}&\quad {40} \times {7\text{ tens}}\\ 3{,}066 \end{align}$

Here is the completed equation using partial products:  $\begin{align} 73&\\ \underline{{} \times 42}&\\ {6}&\quad {2} \times {3\text{ ones}}\\ {140}&\quad {2} \times{7\text{ tens}}\\ {120}&\quad {40} \times {3\text{ ones}} \\ \underline{{}+{2{,}800}}&\quad {40} \times {7\text{ tens}}\\ 3{,}066 \end{align}$

question.content: **Use partial products to multiply $35\times77$.**  || -:|-: | :- |$35$ | |$\underline{{}\times 77}$ | Step 1|$2{,}100$ | $70 \times 3$ tens Step 2|$350$ |  $70 \times 5$ ones Step 3|$210$|  $7 \times 3$ tens Step 4|$\underline{{}+}$__ | $7 \times {}$  Step 5| |

hints.content: Let's break up the top factor by place value.  Then we can multiply each part by $70$ and by $7$ to get parts of the product.  Finally, let's add up all of partial products to get the total product.
$\begin{align} \blueE{3}5&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{7}7}&\\ \goldE{2{,}100}&\quad \maroonE{70} \times \blueE{3\text{ tens}} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 3\blueE{5}&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{7}7}&\\ 2{,}100&\quad 70 \times 3\text{ tens}\\ \goldE{350}&\quad \maroonE{70} \times \blueE{5\text{ ones}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} \blueE{3}5&\\ \underline{{} \times 7\maroonE{7}}&\\ 2{,}100&\quad 70 \times 3\text{ tens}\\ 350&\quad 70 \times 5\text{ ones}\\ \goldE{210}&\quad \maroonE{7} \times \blueE{3\text{ tens}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 3\blueE{5}&\\ \underline{{} \times 7\maroonE{7}}&\\ 2{,}100&\quad 70 \times 3\text{ tens}\\ 350&\quad 70 \times 5\text{ ones}\\ 210&\quad 7\times 3\text{ tens} \\ \goldE{35}&\quad \maroonE{7} \times \blueE{5\text{ ones}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 35&\\ \underline{{} \times 77}&\\ \purpleD{2{,}100}&\quad 70\times 3\text{ tens}\\ \purpleD{350}&\quad 70 \times 5\text{ ones}\\ \purpleD{210}&\quad 7\times 3\text{ tens} \\ \underline{{}+\purpleD{35}}&\quad 7 \times 5\text{ ones}\\ 2{,}695 \end{align}$

Here is the completed equation using partial products:  $\begin{align} 35&\\ \underline{{} \times 77}&\\ {2{,}100}&\quad 70\times 3\text{ tens}\\ {350}&\quad 70 \times 5\text{ ones}\\ {210}&\quad 7\times 3\text{ tens} \\ \underline{{}+{35}}&\quad 7 \times 5\text{ ones}\\ 2{,}695 \end{align}$

question.content: **Use partial products to multiply $85\times 61$.**  || -:|-: | :- |$85$ | |$\underline{{}\times 61}$ | Step 1|$5$ | $1 \times 5$ ones Step 2| |  ${}\times 8$ tens Step 3|$300$ | $60 \times 5$ ones Step 4|$\underline{{}+4{,}800}$ | $60 \times 8$ tens Step 5| |

hints.content: Let's break up the top factor by place value.  Then we can multiply each part by $60$ and by $1$ to get parts of the product.  Finally, let's add up all of partial products to get the total product.
$\begin{align} 8\blueE{5}&\\ \underline{{} \times 6\maroonE{1}}&\\ \goldE{5}&\quad \maroonE{1} \times \blueE{5\text{ ones}} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} \blueE{8}5&\\ \underline{{} \times 6\maroonE{1}}&\\ 5&\quad{1} \times{5\text{ ones}}\\ \goldE{80}&\quad \maroonE{1} \times \blueE{8\text{ tens}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 8\blueE{5}&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{6}1}&\\ 5&\quad{1} \times{5\text{ ones}}\\ {80}&\quad{1} \times {8\text{ tens}}\\ \goldE{300}&\quad \maroonE{60} \times \blueE{5\text{ ones}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} \blueE{8}5&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{6}1}&\\ 5&\quad{1} \times{5\text{ ones}}\\ {80}&\quad{1} \times {8\text{ tens}}\\ {300}&\quad {60} \times{5\text{ ones}}\\ \underline{{}+\goldE{4{,}800}}&\quad \maroonE{60} \times \blueE{8\text{ tens}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 85&\\ \underline{{} \times 61}&\\ \purpleD{5}&\quad{1} \times{5\text{ ones}}\\ \purpleD{80}&\quad{1} \times {8\text{ tens}}\\ \purpleD{300}&\quad {60} \times{5\text{ ones}}\\ \underline{{}+\purpleD{4{,}800}}&\quad 60\times8\text{ tens}\\ 5{,}185 \end{align}$

Here is the completed equation using partial products:  $\begin{align} 85&\\ \underline{{} \times 61}&\\ 5&\quad{1} \times{5\text{ ones}}\\ 80&\quad{1} \times {8\text{ tens}}\\ 300&\quad {60} \times{5\text{ ones}}\\ \underline{{}+4{,}800}&\quad 60\times8\text{ tens}\\ 5{,}185 \end{align}$

question.content: **Use partial products to multiply $28\times14$.**  || -:|-: | :- |$28$ | |$\underline{{}\times 14}$ | Step 1|$200$ | $10 \times 20$ Step 2|$80$|  $10 \times 8$ Step 3|| $4 \times {}$  Step 4|$\underline{{}+32}$ | $4 \times 8$ Step 5| |

hints.content: Let's break up the top factor by place value.  Then we can multiply each part by $10$ and by $4$ to get parts of the product.  Finally, let's add up all of partial products to get the total product.
$\begin{align} \blueE{2}8&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{1}4}&\\ \goldE{200}&\quad \maroonE{10} \times \blueE{20} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 2\blueE{8}&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{1}4}&\\ 200&\quad 10 \times 20\\ \goldE{80}&\quad \maroonE{10} \times \blueE{8} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} \blueE{2}8&\\ \underline{{} \times 1\maroonE{4}}&\\ 200&\quad 10 \times 20\\ 80&\quad 10\times 8\\ \goldE{80}&\quad \maroonE{4} \times \blueE{20} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 2\blueE{8}&\\ \underline{{} \times 1\maroonE{4}}&\\ 200&\quad 10 \times 20\\ 80&\quad 10\times 8\\ 80&\quad 4\times 20\\ \goldE{32}&\quad \maroonE{4} \times \blueE{8} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 28&\\ \underline{{} \times 14}&\\ \purpleD{200}&\quad 10\times 20\\ \purpleD{80}&\quad 10\times 8\\ \purpleD{80}&\quad 4\times 20\\ \underline{{}+\purpleD{32}}&\quad 4\times 8\\ 392 \end{align}$

Here is the completed equation using partial products:  $\begin{align} 28&\\ \underline{{} \times 14}&\\ {200}&\quad 10\times 20\\ {80}&\quad 10\times 8\\ {80}&\quad 4\times 20\\ \underline{{}+{32}}&\quad 4\times 8\\ 392 \end{align}$

question.content: **Use partial products to multiply $39\times92$.**  || -:|-: | :- |$39$ | |$\underline{{}\times 92}$ | Step 1|$18$ | $2 \times 9$ Step 2|$60$| $2 \times 30$ Step 3| | $90 \times {}$  Step 4|$\underline{{}+2{,}700}$ | $90 \times 30$ Step 5| |

hints.content: Let's break up the top factor by place value.  Then we can multiply each part by $90$ and by $2$ to get parts of the product.  Finally, let's add up all of partial products to get the total product.
$\begin{align} 3\blueE{9}&\\ \underline{{} \times 9\maroonE{2}}&\\ \goldE{18}&\quad \maroonE{2} \times \blueE{9} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} \blueE{3}9&\\ \underline{{} \times 9\maroonE{2}}&\\ 18&\quad {2} \times {9}\\ \goldE{60}&\quad \maroonE{2} \times \blueE{30} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 3\blueE{9}&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{9}2}&\\ 18&\quad {2} \times {9}\\ {60}&\quad {2} \times{30}\\ \goldE{810}&\quad \maroonE{90} \times \blueE{9} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} \blueE{3}9&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{9}2}&\\ 18&\quad {2} \times {9}\\ {60}&\quad {2} \times{30}\\ {810}&\quad{90} \times {9}\\ \underline{{}+\goldE{2{,}700}}&\quad \maroonE{90} \times \blueE{30} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 39&\\ \underline{{} \times 92}&\\ \purpleD{18}&\quad {2} \times {9}\\ \purpleD{60}&\quad {2} \times{30}\\ \purpleD{810}&\quad{90} \times {9}\\ \underline{{}+\purpleD{2{,}700}}&\quad {90} \times {30}\\ 3{,}588 \end{align}$

Here is the completed equation using partial products:  $\begin{align} 39&\\ \underline{{} \times 92}&\\ 18&\quad {2} \times {9}\\ {60}&\quad {2} \times{30}\\ {810}&\quad{90} \times {9}\\ \underline{{}+{2{,}700}}&\quad {90} \times {30}\\ 3{,}588 \end{align}$

question.content: **Use partial products to multiply $56\times47$.**  ||| -:| -: | :- |$56$ | |$\underline{{}\times 47}$ | Step 1 | $2{,}000$ | $40 \times 50$ Step 2 |  |  ${} \times 6$ Step 3| $350$|  $7 \times 50$ Step 4| $\underline{{}+42}$ | $7 \times 6$ Step 5 |  |

hints.content: Let's break up the top factor by place value.  Then we can multiply each part by $40$ and by $7$ to get parts of the product.  Finally, let's add up all of partial products to get the total product.
$\begin{align} \blueE{5}6&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{4}7}&\\ \tealE{2{,}000}&\quad \maroonE{40} \times \blueE{50}\\ \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 5\blueE{6}&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{4}7}&\\ 2{,}000&\quad 40 \times 50\\ \tealE{240}&\quad \maroonE{40} \times \blueE{6}\\ \end{align}$
$\begin{align} \blueE{5}6&\\ \underline{{} \times 4\maroonE{7}}&\\ 2{,}000&\quad 40 \times 50\\ 240&\quad 40 \times 6\\ \tealE{350}&\quad \maroonE{7} \times \blueE{50} \\ \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 5\blueE{6}&\\ \underline{{} \times 4\maroonE{7}}&\\ 2{,}000&\quad 40 \times 50\\ 240&\quad 40 \times 6\\ 350&\quad 7 \times 50\\ \tealE{42}&\quad \maroonE{7} \times \blueE{6}\\ \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 56&\\ \underline{{} \times 47}&\\ \purpleD{2{,}000}&\quad 40\times 50\\ \purpleD{240}&\quad 40 \times 6\\ \purpleD{350}&\quad 7 \times 50\\ \underline{{}+\purpleD{42}}&\quad 7\times 6\\ 2{,}632 \end{align}$

Here is the completed equation using partial products:  $\begin{align} 56&\\ \underline{{} \times 47}&\\ {2{,}000}&\quad 40\times 50\\ {240}&\quad 40 \times 6\\ {350}&\quad 7 \times 50\\ \underline{{}+{42}}&\quad 7\times 6\\ 2{,}632 \end{align}$

question.content: Greg tried to evaluate $86\times37$ using partial products, but he made a mistake.  His work is below.  $\begin{array}{llrr} &&86 \\ &&\underline{{}\times37} \\ &\goldE{\text{Step 1}}&\goldE{ 2{,}400}& \goldE{30\times 80}\\ &\maroonE{\text{Step 2}}&\maroonE{18}& \maroonE{3\times 6}\\ &\tealE{\text{Step 3}}&\tealE{560}& \tealE{7\times 80}\\ &\blueE{\text{Step 4}}&\underline{{}+\blueE{42}}& \blueE{7\times6}\\ &\purpleE{\text{Step 5}}&\purpleE{3{,}020}&  \end{array}$  **Find Greg's mistake.**

hints.content: Partial products help us multiply larger numbers.  We can break the first factor apart by place value and multiply the parts *in any order* by the parts of the second factor. Then we add those products to get the final product.  [[☃ explanation 1]]  Let's take a look at how Greg broke apart the numbers to multiply.

###Step $1$  $\begin{align} \goldE{8}6&\\ \underline{{} \times \goldE{3}7}&\\ \goldE{2{,}400}&\quad \goldE{30} \times \goldE{80}\\ \end{align}$  There are $3$ tens in $37$, and there are $8$ tens in $86$.  Also, $\goldE{30}\times\goldE{80}=\goldE{2{,}400}$, so Greg did not make a mistake in step $1$.

$\begin{align} 8\maroonE{6} \\ \underline{{}\times\maroonE{3}7} \\ { 2{,}400}&\quad {30\times 80}\\ \maroonE{180}& \quad\maroonE{30\times 6}  \end{align}$  Greg said the value of the $3$ in $\maroonE{3}7$ is $3\text{ ones}$, not $\maroonE{3\text{ tens}}$, so Greg made a mistake in step $2$.
Greg made a mistake in step $2$.

question.content: Leah tried to evaluate $15\times58$ using partial products, but she made a mistake.  Her work is below.  $\begin{array}{llrr} &&15 \\ &&\underline{{}\times58} \\ &\goldE{\text{Step 1}}&\goldE{500}& \goldE{50\times 10}\\ &\maroonE{\text{Step 2}}&\maroonE{250}& \maroonE{50\times 5}\\ &\tealE{\text{Step 3}}&\tealE{800}& \tealE{8\times 10}\\ &\blueE{\text{Step 4}}&\underline{{}+\blueE{40}}& \blueE{8\times5}\\ &\purpleE{\text{Step 5}}&\purpleE{1{,}590}&  \end{array}$  **Find Leah's mistake.**

hints.content: Partial products help us multiply larger numbers.  We can break the first factor apart by place value and multiply the parts *in any order* by the parts of the second factor. Then we add those products to get the final product.  [[☃ explanation 1]]  Let's take a look at how Leah broke apart the numbers to multiply.

###Step $1$  $\begin{align} \goldE{1}5&\\ \underline{{} \times \goldE{5}8}&\\ \goldE{500}&\quad \goldE{50} \times \goldE{10} \end{align}$  There are $5$ tens in $58$, and there is $1$ ten in $15$.  Also, $\goldE{50}\times\goldE{10}=\goldE{500}$, so Leah did not make a mistake in step $1$.

###Step $2$  $\begin{align} 1\maroonE{5}&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE{5}8}&\\ 500&\quad 50 \times 10\\ \maroonE{250}&\quad \maroonE{50} \times \maroonE{5} \end{align}$  There are $5$ tens in $58$, and there are $5$ ones in $15$.  Also, $\maroonE{50}\times\maroonE{5}=\maroonE{250}$, so Leah did not make a mistake in step $2$.

###Step $3$  $\begin{align} \tealE{1}5&\\ \underline{{} \times 5\tealE{8}}&\\ 500&\quad 50 \times 10 \\ 250&\quad 50 \times 5 \\ \tealE{80}&\quad \tealE{8} \times \tealE{10} \end{align}$  Leah said that $\tealE{8}\times\tealE{10}$ equals $800$, so Leah made a mistake in step $3$.
Leah made a mistake in step $3$.

question.content: Matt tried to evaluate $49\times24$ using partial products, but he made a mistake.  His work is below.  $\begin{array}{llrr} &&49 \\ &&\underline{{}\times24} \\ &\blueE{\text{Step 1}}&\blueE{36}& \blueE{4\times9}\\ &\tealE{\text{Step 2}}&\tealE{160}& \tealE{4\times 40}\\ &\maroonE{\text{Step 3}}&\maroonE{180}& \maroonE{20\times 9}\\ &\goldE{\text{Step 4}}&\underline{{}+\goldE{800}}& \goldE{20\times 40}\\ &\purpleE{\text{Step 5}}&\purpleE{1{,}076}&  \end{array}$  **Find Matt's mistake.**

hints.content: Partial products help us multiply larger numbers.  We can break the first factor apart by place value and multiply the parts *in any order* by the parts of the second factor. Then we add those products to get the final product.  [[☃ explanation 1]]  Let's take a look at how Matt broke apart the numbers to multiply.

###Step $1$  $\begin{align} 4\blueE{9}&\\ \underline{{} \times 2\blueE{4}}&\\ \blueE{36}&\quad \blueE{4} \times \blueE{9} \end{align}$  There are $4$ ones in $24$, and there are $9$ ones in $49$.  Also, $\blueE4\times\blueE9=\blueE{36}$, so Matt did not make a mistake in step $1$.

###Step $2$  $\begin{align} \tealE{4}9&\\ \underline{{} \times 2\tealE{4}}&\\ {36}&\quad {4} \times {9}\\ \tealE{160}&\quad \tealE{4} \times \tealE{40} \end{align}$  There are $4$ ones in $24$, and there are $4$ tens in $49$.  Also, $\tealE4\times\tealE{40}=\tealE{160}$, so Matt did not make a mistake in step $2$.

###Step $3$  $\begin{align} 4\maroonE{9}&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE2{4}}&\\ {36}&\quad {4} \times {9}\\ {160}&\quad {4} \times{40} \\ {\maroonE{180}}&\quad {\maroonE{20}} \times\maroonE{9} \end{align}$  There are $2$ tens in $24$, and there are $9$ ones in $49$.  Also, $\maroonE{20}\times\maroonE{9}=\maroonE{180}$, so Matt did not make a mistake in step $3$.

###Step $4$  $\begin{align} \goldE{4}{9}&\\ \underline{{} \times \goldE{2}{4}}&\\ {36}&\quad {4} \times {9}\\ {160}&\quad {4} \times{40} \\ {{180}}&\quad {20} \times{9} \\ \underline{~~~\goldE{800}}&\quad {\goldE{20}} \times\goldE{40} \end{align}$  There are $2$ tens in $24$, and there are $4$ tens in $49$.  Also, $\goldE{20}\times\goldE{40}=\goldE{800}$, so Matt did not make a mistake in step $4$.

###Step $5$  $\begin{align} 49&\\ \underline{{} \times24}&\\ \purpleD{36}&\quad 4 \times 9\\ \purpleD{160}&\quad 4 \times40 \\ \purpleD{180}&\quad 20 \times9 \\ +\underline{~~~\purpleD{800}}&\quad {20} \times{40} \\ \purpleD{1{,}176} \end{align}$  Matt said that $\purpleD{36 + 160+ 180 + 800}$ equals $1{,}076$, so Matt made a mistake in step $5$.
Matt made a mistake in step $5$.

question.content: Nick tried to evaluate $42\times36$ using partial products, but he made a mistake.  His work is below.  $\begin{array}{llrr} &&42 \\ &&\underline{{}\times36} \\ &\goldE{\text{Step 1}}&\goldE{ 1{,}200}& \goldE{30\times 40}\\ &\maroonE{\text{Step 2}}&\maroonE{600}& \maroonE{30\times 20}\\ &\tealE{\text{Step 3}}&\tealE{240}& \tealE{6\times 40}\\ &\blueE{\text{Step 4}}&\underline{{}+\blueE{12}}& \blueE{6\times2}\\ &\purpleE{\text{Step 5}}&\purpleE{2{,}052}&  \end{array}$  **Find Nick's mistake.**

hints.content: Partial products help us multiply larger numbers.  We can break the first factor apart by place value and multiply the parts *in any order* by the parts of the second factor. Then we add those products to get the final product.  [[☃ explanation 1]]  Let's take a look at how Nick broke apart the numbers to multiply.

###Step $1$  $\begin{align} \goldE{4}2&\\ \underline{{} \times \goldE{3}6}&\\ \goldE{1{,}200}&\quad \goldE{30} \times \goldE{40} \end{align}$  There are $3$ tens in $36$, and there are $4$ tens in $42$.  Also, $\goldE{30}\times\goldE{40}=\goldE{1{,}200}$, so Nick did not make a mistake in step $1$.

###Step $2$  $\begin{align} 4\maroonE{2}&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE3{6}}&\\ {1{,}200}&\quad {30} \times{40} \\ {\maroonE{60}}&\quad {\maroonE{30}} \times\maroonE{2} \\ \end{align}$  Nick said the value of the $2$ in $4\maroonE{2}$ is $2\text{ tens}$, not $\maroonE{2\text{ ones}}$, so Nick made a mistake in step $2$.
Nick made a mistake in step $2$.

question.content: Jana tried to evaluate $75\times62$ using partial products, but she made a mistake.  Her work is below.  $\begin{array}{llrr} &&75 \\ &&\underline{{}\times62} \\ &\blueE{\text{Step 1}}&\blueE{10}& \blueE{2\times5}\\ &\tealE{\text{Step 2}}&\tealE{140}& \tealE{2\times 70}\\ &\maroonE{\text{Step 3}}&\maroonE{300}& \maroonE{60\times 5}\\ &\goldE{\text{Step 4}}&\underline{{}+\goldE{ 420}}& \goldE{60\times 70}\\ &\purpleE{\text{Step 5}}&\purpleE{870}&  \end{array}$  **Find Jana's mistake.**

hints.content: Partial products help us multiply larger numbers.  We can break the first factor apart by place value and multiply the parts *in any order* by the parts of the second factor. Then we add those products to get the final product.  [[☃ explanation 1]]  Let's take a look at how Jana broke apart the numbers to multiply.

###Step $1$  $\begin{align} 7\blueE{5}&\\ \underline{{} \times 6\blueE{2}}&\\ \blueE{10}&\quad \blueE{2} \times \blueE{5} \end{align}$  There are $2$ ones in $62$, and there are $5$ ones in $75$.  Also, $\blueE2\times\blueE5=\blueE{10}$, so Jana did not make a mistake in step $1$.

###Step $2$  $\begin{align} \tealE{7}5&\\ \underline{{} \times 6\tealE{2}}&\\ {10}&\quad {2} \times {5}\\ \tealE{140}&\quad \tealE{2} \times \tealE{70} \end{align}$  There are $2$ ones in $62$, and there are $7$ tens in $75$.  Also, $\tealE2\times\tealE{70}=\tealE{140}$, so Jana did not make a mistake in step $2$.

###Step $3$  $\begin{align} 7\maroonE{5}&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE6{2}}&\\ {10}&\quad {2} \times {5}\\ {140}&\quad {2} \times{70} \\ {\maroonE{300}}&\quad {\maroonE{60}} \times\maroonE{5} \end{align}$  There are $6$ tens in $62$, and there are $5$ ones in $75$.  Also, $\maroonE{60}\times\maroonE{5}=\maroonE{300}$, so Jana did not make a mistake in step $3$.

###Step $4$  $\begin{align} \goldE{7}{5}&\\ \underline{{} \times \goldE{6}{2}}&\\ {10}&\quad {2} \times {5}\\ {140}&\quad {2} \times{70} \\ {{300}}&\quad {60} \times{5} \\ \underline{~~~\goldE{4{,}200}}&\quad {\goldE{60}} \times\goldE{70} \\ \end{align}$  Jana said that $\goldE{60}\times\goldE{70}$ equals $420$, so Jana made a make a mistake in step $4$.
Jana made a mistake in step $4$.

question.content: Molly tried to evaluate $93\times51$ using partial products, but she made a mistake.  Her work is below.  $\begin{array}{llrr} &&93 \\ &&\underline{{}\times51} \\ &\blueE{\text{Step 1}}&\blueE{3}& \blueE{1\times3}\\ &\tealE{\text{Step 2}}&\tealE{90}& \tealE{1\times 90}\\ &\maroonE{\text{Step 3}}&\maroonE{150}& \maroonE{50\times 3}\\ &\goldE{\text{Step 4}}&\underline{{}+\goldE{ 4{,}500}}& \goldE{50\times 90}\\ &\purpleE{\text{Step 5}}&\purpleE{4{,}650}&  \end{array}$  **Find Molly's mistake.**

hints.content: Partial products help us multiply larger numbers.  We can break the first factor apart by place value and multiply the parts *in any order* by the parts of the second factor. Then we add those products to get the final product.  [[☃ explanation 1]]  Let's take a look at how Molly broke apart the numbers to multiply.

###Step $1$  $\begin{align} 9\blueE{3}&\\ \underline{{} \times 5\blueE{1}}&\\ \blueE{3}&\quad \blueE{1} \times \blueE{3} \end{align}$  There is $1$ one in $51$ and there are $3$ ones in $93$.  Also, $\blueE1\times\blueE3=\blueE{3}$, so Molly did not make a mistake in step $1$.

###Step $2$  $\begin{align} \tealE{9}3&\\ \underline{{} \times 5\tealE{1}}&\\ {3}&\quad {1} \times {3}\\ \tealE{90}&\quad \tealE{1} \times \tealE{90} \end{align}$  There is $1$ one in $51$ and there are $9$ tens in $93$. Also, $\tealE1\times\tealE{90}=\tealE{90}$, so Molly did not make a mistake in step $2$.

###Step $3$  $\begin{align} 9\maroonE{3}&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonE5{1}}&\\ {3}&\quad {1} \times {3}\\ {90}&\quad {1} \times{90} \\ {\maroonE{150}}&\quad {\maroonE{50}} \times\maroonE{3} \end{align}$  There are $5$ tens in $51$ and there are $3$ ones in $93$.  Also, $\maroonE{50}\times\maroonE{3}=\maroonE{150}$, so Molly did not make a mistake in step $3$.

###Step $4$  $\begin{align} \goldE{9}{3}&\\ \underline{{} \times \goldE{5}{1}}&\\ {3}&\quad {1} \times {3}\\ {90}&\quad {1} \times{90} \\ {{150}}&\quad {50} \times{3} \\ \underline{~~~\goldE{4{,}500}}&\quad {\goldE{50}} \times\goldE{90} \end{align}$  There are $5$ tens in $51$ and there are $9$ tens in $93$. Also, $\goldE{50}\times\goldE{90}=\goldE{4{,}500}$, so Molly did not make a mistake in step $4$.

###Step $5$  $\begin{align} 93&\\ \underline{{} \times51}&\\ \purpleE3&\quad 1 \times 3\\ \purpleE{90}&\quad 1 \times90 \\ \purpleE{150}&\quad 50 \times3 \\ +\underline{~~~\purpleE{4{,}500}}&\quad {50} \times{90} \\ \purpleE{4{,}743} \end{align}$  Molly said that $\purpleE{3 + 90+ 150 + 4{,}500}$ equals $4{,}650$, so Molly made a mistake in step $5$.
Molly made a mistake in step $5$.
